Continuing to dip my toes in the Twitter world. I think I'll try to avoid politics -- we'll see how successful I am -- and stick primarily to econometrics.

Those who use experimental data for causal inference may be interested in a recent paper in Econometric Reviews with my former student, Akanksha Negi. With random sampling, we prove separate linear regression adjustment can improve over the simple difference-in-means.

More promising is the nonlinear methods when Y is binary, fractional, or nonnegative. Logistic regression in the first two cases and Poisson regression for Y >= 0 are fully robust and often much more efficient.
